contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to things that are done on earth. Alternate translation: “on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: under heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to things that are done on earth. Alternate translation: “on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: under heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the gold and other wealth that neighboring countries were forced to pay to the king of Israel. Alternate translation: “that I acquired from the treasures of kings and the rulers of provinces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the treasures of kings and provinces

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he had many concubines that he enjoyed sleeping with, as any man enjoys sleeping with women. Alternate translation: “I greatly enjoyed many concubines, as would delight any man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the delights of the children of humanity—and many concubines

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all the previous rulers of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “than all the kings who had ruled before me in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: than all who were before me in Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that all people and all animals die and decay and become part of the soil. Alternate translation: “Everything dies and goes to the same place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Everything is going to the same place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to those who are dead and to those who are alive. Alternate translation: “both those who are dead and those who are living” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: both of them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This person has no family. Alternate translation: “he has no family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: no son or brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of two people keeping each other warm on a cold night. Alternate translation: “If two people lie down together at night, they can be warm” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: If two lie down together, they can be warm

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he had poor parents. Alternate translation: “he was born to poor parents who lived in the land that he will someday rule” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he was born poor in his kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that it is foolish to delay in fulfilling a vow that you have made to God. Alternate translation: “do not foolishly delay in doing it, because God is not pleased with foolish people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: do not delay to do it, for God has no pleasure in fools

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the birth and death of a person and expresses the same idea as the previous verse. This refers to women as well as men. Alternate translation: “as people bring nothing into the world when they are born, so they take nothing with them when they die and leave this world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-gendernotations]])
contextId.quoteString: as a person comes, so he goes away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he dies like all other people. Alternate translation: “he dies and go to the same place as everyone else” or “he goes to the grave just like everyone else” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he goes to the same place as everyone else

contextId.occurrenceNote: here the word “this” refers to all of the things the author has written about. Alternate translation: “All this that I have already written about have I proven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: All this have I proven

contextId.occurrenceNote: One should love the wife he has. Alternate translation: “Since you have a wife whom you love, live happily with her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Live happily with the wife whom you love

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the way that he acts. Alternate translation: “he is stupid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: his thinking is deficient

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a snake that was hiding inside the wall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a snake can bite him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that the leaders are more concerned with having a good time than with leading the nation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: begin feasting in the morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that the son has been trained by his elders in the customs of being a good king. Alternate translation: “king has trained by nobles” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: king is the son of nobles

contextId.occurrenceNote: A lazy person does not keep up on the regular house maintenance. Alternate translation: “Because a lazy person does not repair his house, the roof sinks in” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Because of laziness the roof sinks in

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the voice of the birds startle the men awake. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “when the voice of a bird startles men awake” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: when men are startled at the voice of a bird

contextId.occurrenceNote: To fold the hands is a gesture of laziness and is another way of saying that the person refuses to work. Alternate translation: “The fool refuses to work” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: The fool folds his hands and does not work

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wearing white clothes and anointing one’s head with oil were both signs of gladness and celebration. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Let your clothes be always white and your head anointed with oil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “almond tree” is a tree that blossoms in the winter with white flowers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: when the almond tree blossoms

contextId.occurrenceNote: A grasshopper is a large, straight-winged insect with long, jointed back legs that give it the ability to jump a long way. Here it can only drag itself because it has gotten old and weak. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: when grasshoppers drag themselves along

contextId.occurrenceNote: The direct quotation can be translated as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: “I said that it is crazy to laugh at things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.quoteString: I said about laughter, “It is crazy,”

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer is speaking to the people of the nation as if they were the land itself, and he is speaking to the land as if it were a person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe to you, land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer is speaking to the people of the nation as if they were the land itself, and he is speaking to the land as if it were a person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: blessed are you, land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a double negative. Alternate translation: “he has everything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: he lacks nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how diligently he studied. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to study and to search out

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “madness” and “folly” share similar meanings and refer to foolish thinking and behavior, respectively. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: madness and folly

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words share similar meanings and refer to beautiful orchards of fruit trees. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: gardens and parks

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how difficult the person’s work is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: painful and stressful

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and refer to every action that people do. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: every matter and every deed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “just” and “right” mean basically the same thing and refer to the kind of treatment that people deserve. Alternate translation: “fair treatment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: just and right treatment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “good” and “suitable” mean basically the same thing. The second intensifies the meaning of the first. Alternate translation: “what I have seen to be the best thing to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: what I have seen to be good and suitable

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing. They refer to money and the things that a person can buy with money. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: riches and wealth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing. They refer to money and the things that a person can buy with money. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: riches, wealth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words both refer to ways in which people trap animals to emphasize how the woman traps men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: snares and nets

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the person’s work may prosper, no matter what time he has done it. Alternate translation: “whether the seed that you planted in the morning or the seed that you planted in the evening” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: whether morning or evening, or this or that

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood subject may be supplied. Alternate translation: “the things that will happen in the future” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: that will happen in the future

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood verb may be supplied. Alternate translation: “much more than any other king had” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: much more than any king

contextId.occurrenceNote: “a large amount.” It is understood that this refer to profit gained. Alternate translation: “two handfuls of profit” or “a large amount of profit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: two handfuls

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that this refers to people dying. Alternate translation: “the sinner will die … the man who fears to make an oath will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: will the sinner & will the man who fears to make an oath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to dying. Alternate translation: “he will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: he will leave

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a polite expression for death. Alternate translation: “after he dies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: after he passes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to when a person dies. Alternate translation: “when he will die” or “when the time of his death will come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: when his time will come

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to death. Alternate translation: “Then man goes to the place of the dead forever” or “Then a person dies and never returns to life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: Then man goes to his eternal home

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration used to emphasize a large number of people. Alternate translation: “There are very many people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: There is no end to all the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to things that are done on earth. Alternate translation: “on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: under the sun

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this word to draw attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “indeed” or “really” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: look

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. “I continued to act wisely” or “I continued to be wise” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: my wisdom remained with me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “pays attention and looks to see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: uses his eyes in his head to see

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “tries anxiously” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: tries in his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here man’s mind is referred to as his “soul” to emphasize his deep thoughts. Alternate translation: “his mind does not rest” or “he continues to worry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his soul does not find rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: There are other men who rule over the men in authority. Alternate translation: “men who have even more authority than they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: even higher ones over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this word here to draw his reader’s attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Pay attention” or “Listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Look

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “as long as God allows us to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: during the days of this life that God has given us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “he” refers to the person to whom God has given a gift. The phrase “call to mind” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “he does not remember” or “he does not think about” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he does not call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the things that happened during his lifetime. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “the things that have happened during his lifetime” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the days of his life

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the death of the baby being as unexplainable as “darkness.” Alternate translation: “dies unexplainably” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: passes away in darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “must think seriously about this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: must take this to heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to being sad. Alternate translation: “an experience that makes a person sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: sadness of face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “those who are alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: those who see the sun

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “times” is an idiom for “things happening.” Alternate translation: “When good things happen … when bad things happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: When times are good & when times are bad

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “side by side” is an idiom that means “this one” and “this one.” Alternate translation: “both to exist” or “there to be both good and bad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: both to exist side by side

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of wisdom being difficult to understand as if it were something located far away or in a very deep place. Alternate translation: “difficult to understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: far off and very deep

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the person’s face will show that he has wisdom. Alternate translation: “shows on his face” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: causes his face to shine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “his harsh appearance” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the hardness of his face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “when he will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the day of his death

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “it will be better” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “life will be better for those who respect God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: it will be better for those who respect God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “for as long as God allows him to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: for all the days of his life that God has given him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “what happens and when it happens affect them all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: time and chance affect them all

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “at times when they do not expect them to happen” or “that suddenly happen to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: that suddenly fall upon them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “right” and “left” refer to what is right and wrong. Alternate translation: “tends to doing what is right … tends to doing what is wrong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: tends to the right & tends to the left

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. AT” “unimportant positions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: low positions

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “keeps on talking” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: multiplies words

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “Remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author uses irony to rebuke the person’s question. Alternate translation: “if you were wise you would not ask this question” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: it is not because of wisdom that you ask this question

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The writer uses merisms to describe various aspects of life from one extreme to the other. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The writer concludes using merisms to describe various aspects of life from one extreme to the other. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the beginning and the end and all that is in between. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: from their beginning all the way to their end

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all people, emphasizing the two opposites of righteous and wicked people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: righteous people and wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all people, emphasizing the two opposites of clean and unclean people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: the clean and the unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all people, emphasizing the two opposites of those who sacrifice and those who do not. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: the one who sacrifices and the one who does not sacrifice

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all people, emphasizing the two opposites of good people and sinners. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: As good people & so also will the sinner

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all people, emphasizing the two opposites of those who swear oaths and those who do not.(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: the one who swears & so also will the man who fears to make an oath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “south” and “north” represent any direction. Alternate translation: “in any direction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: toward the south or toward the north

contextId.occurrenceNote: “are only mist.” The author speaks of useless and meaningless things as if they were “vapor.” Just as vapor disappears and does not last, things have no lasting value. Alternate translation: “are as useless as vapor” or “are meaningless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: amount to vapor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author says that everything that people do is as useless as if they were trying to control the wind. Alternate translation: “are as useless as trying to control the wind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: chasing the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how happiness only lasts for a short time as if it were a temporary breeze. Alternate translation: “this also only lasted for a short time, like a temporary breeze” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: this also was just a temporary breeze

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of thinking hard for a long time as if it were exploring. Also, the author speaks of his feelings and his thoughts as if they were his “heart.” Alternate translation: “I thought hard about” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I explored in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a wise man making wise decisions as walking and paying attention to where he is going. Alternate translation: “The wise man is like a person who uses his eyes to see where he is going” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The wise man uses his eyes in his head to see where he is going

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares a fool making bad decisions to someone walking in darkness. Alternate translation: “the fool is like a person who walks in the dark” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the fool walks in darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author speaks of everything being as temporary as if it were a breath of air. The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that everything is temporary. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Everything is just a breath.” or “Everything is as temporary as a breath.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: is not everything just a breath?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a person destroying himself as if he were eating his own body. Alternate translation: “as a result, he causes his own ruin” or “and as a result, he destroys himself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: so his food is his own flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of three people together being stronger as if they were a three-strand rope. Alternate translation: “three people are even stronger, like a three-strand rope that” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a three-strand rope

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of people spending wealth as if they were “eating” it. Alternate translation: “who use it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who consume it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a person’s sleep being fulfilling and peaceful as if it were sweet like something he eats. Alternate translation: “The sleep of a working man is peaceful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The sleep of a working man is sweet

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that a man is naked when he is born. In addition to being without clothing, here the word “naked” emphasizes that people are born without any possessions. Alternate translation: “As a man is naked and owns nothing when he is born … he will leave this life the same way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: As a man comes from his mother’s womb & he will leave naked

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) This speaks of the person receiving no lasting profit as if he were trying to control the wind. Alternate translation: “tries to shepherd the wind” or “work that is as useless as trying to shepherd the wind” or (2) This implies that the person only receives the air that he breaths as his profit. Alternate translation: “works to receive the air he breathes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: works for the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a person mourning throughout his life as if he always ate in darkness. Here “darkness” represents sadness and mourning. Alternate translation: “He spends his life in mourning and sadness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: During his days he eats with darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here evil is spoken of as something that is a heavy load to carry. Alternate translation: “it causes hardship for people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it weighs heavy on men

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of no one knowing the baby’s name as if it were a hidden object. Alternate translation: “no one knows its name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: its name remains hidden

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a person being full of anger as if the anger lived inside him. This speaks of the anger being in the person’s heart because the “heart” is thought to be the source of a person’s emotions. Alternate translation: “foolish people are full of anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: anger resides in the hearts of fools

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “being wise in your own opinion” or “being wise according to your own judgement” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: wise in your own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of striving to be wise as if “wisdom” were an object that a person could hold on to. Alternate translation: “commit yourself to this wisdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: take hold of this wisdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of striving to be righteous as if “righteousness” were an object that a person could hold on to. Alternate translation: “you should not stop trying to be righteous” or “you should keep trying to be righteous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you should not let go of righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer says that the seductive woman is like traps that hunters use to catch animals. The author speaks of a woman being seductive as if she traps men like a hunter traps animals. Her “heart” represents her thoughts and emotions. Alternate translation: “any woman who traps men by seducing them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: any woman whose heart is full of snares and nets, and whose hands are chains

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” refers to her power and control. This speaks of her being seductive as if hands were chains that she bound people with. Alternate translation: “from whom no one can escape” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: whose hands are chains

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “they” refers to “humanity.” This speaks of humanity changing from being upright to not being upright as if they were going from one place to another. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they have gone away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) not to be hasty to physically leave the king’s presence or (2) This is a metaphor that speaks of being loyal to the king as being in his presence. Alternate translation: “Do not abandon the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not hurry out of his presence

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is acceptable for God’s purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically clean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the clean

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is not acceptable for God’s purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a metaphor that means a person should be generous with his possessions and will then receive generously from others , or (2) that a person should invest his resources overseas and will make a profit from it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Send out your bread on the waters, for you will find it again after many days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disasters happening is spoken of as if disasters were something that come to a place. Here “on the earth” may imply that these disasters happen to the person who is commanded to share. Alternate translation: “what disasters may happen in the world” or “what bad things may happen to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: what disasters are coming on the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of wind blowing as if wind traveled on a path. Alternate translation: “As you do not know where the wind comes from or where it goes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: As you do not know the path of the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Future time is spoken of as if the “days are coming” And, here the word “darkness” refers to death. Alternate translation: “how many days that he will be dead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: the coming days of darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “vanishing vapor” is a metaphor. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: “No one knows what will happen after he dies” or (2) Alternate translation: “Everything to come is meaningless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Everything to come is vanishing vapor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Refusing to be angry is spoken of as if anger were something that can be forced away. Also, “heart” represents a person’s emotions. Alternate translation: “Refuse to be angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]]and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Drive anger away from your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Future time is spoken of as if the “days are coming” Alternate translation: “before you experience difficult times” or “before bad things happen to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: before the days of difficulty come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Future time is spoken of as if “years arrive” Alternate translation: “before you become old when you say, ‘I no longer enjoy being alive,’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: before the years arrive when you say, “I have no pleasure in them,”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Growing old and dying is spoken of as if the sun and moon go dark and dark clouds return. Alternate translation: “do this before it seems to you that the light of the sun … after the rain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: do this before the light of the sun & after the rain

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The writer describes a house in which various activities stop. This appears to be a metaphor for the human body as it becomes old. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “girls” may be a metaphor for the birds. Alternate translation: “the songs of the birds fade away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the singing of girls’ voices fades away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of dying as if it were one of these various broken items. Death will break the body just as suddenly as people accidentally break these items while they are using them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: before the silver cord is cut & or the water wheel is broken at the well

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the teacher who uses his words to instruct people as if the teacher were a shepherd who uses his tools to lead his flock. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The words of wise people & taught by one shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: Things done in secret is spoken of as if they were an object that was hidden. Alternate translation: “along with everything that people do in secret” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: along with every hidden thing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer probably told people to do the work. Alternate translation: “I had people build houses and plant vineyards for me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I built houses for myself and planted vineyards

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer probably told people to do the work. Alternate translation: “I had people build for me gardens and parks; I had them plant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I built for myself gardens and parks; I planted

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer probably told people to do the work. Alternate translation: “I had them create” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I created

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “provinces” represents the rulers of the provinces. Alternate translation: “the rulers of provinces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: provinces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author’s “work” and “wisdom” represent himself and the things he did in his wisdom. He probably had help with the literal buildings. Alternate translation: “that I worked very hard and wisely to build” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: that my work and wisdom have built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is represented by his “hand” to emphasize how he provides for people. Alternate translation: “from God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: God’s hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “their” refers to human beings. Here the “hearts” of the people represent their thoughts and desires. Alternate translation: “placed eternity in the hearts of human beings” or “caused people to think about eternal things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: placed eternity in their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “tears” represent weeping. Alternate translation: “the oppressed people were weeping” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the tears of oppressed people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that their oppressors were powerful. Here their “hand” represents what thet possess. Alternate translation: “Their oppressors were powerful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Power was in the hand of their oppressors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here knowing represents willingness. Alternate translation: “who is no longer willing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who no longer knows how

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “steps” are a metonym for a person’s conduct. Alternate translation: “Be careful how you conduct yourself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Guard your steps

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person’s “mouth” represents a person’s speech, and the person himself is represented by his “flesh.” Alternate translation: “Do not let what you say cause you to sin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not allow your mouth to cause your flesh to sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase “in his hands” represents ownership. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he leaves no possession for his own son” (See:[[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: his own son, one whom he has fathered, is left with nothing in his hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a man’s possessions are spoken of as if they are fruit that he grew with his labor. Alternate translation: “He can not take any of his possessions with him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He can take none of the fruits of his labor in his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person’s “days” represent his life. Alternate translation: “his life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here putting food in a man’s mouth represents feeding him. Alternate translation: “is to put food in his mouth” or “is to feed him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: is for his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person can see these things because he already has them. Alternate translation: “what a person has” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: what the eyes see

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to things that a person wants but does not have. Alternate translation: “to want what he does not have” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to desire what a wandering appetite craves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person’s “name” is used to represent their reputation. Alternate translation: “A good reputation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: A good name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, the word **heart** refers to a person’s thoughts and emotions. **Gladness** describes either: (1) the state of the emotions of being happy and peaceful or (2) the ability to understand the truth. Alternate translation: “right thinking” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: gladness of heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to the mind. Alternate translation: “ruins a person’s ability to think and judge rightly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: corrupts the heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “spirit” refers to a person’s attitude. Alternate translation: “patient people are better than proud people” or “a patient attitude is better than a prideful attitude” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the people patient in spirit are better than the proud in spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “spirit” refers to a person’s attitude. Alternate translation: “Do not become angry quickly” or “Do not have a bad temper” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not be quick to anger in your spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person’s thoughts are represented by their “heart.” Alternate translation: “in your own thoughts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in your own heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to the mind. Also, here the word “turned” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I directed my thoughts” or “I determined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I turned my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” refers to power and authority. Alternate translation: “under God’s control” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in God’s hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hearts” refers to the thoughts and emotions. Alternate translation: “Human beings are full of evil, and their thoughts are of madness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The hearts of human beings are full of evil, and madness is in their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to the emotions. Alternate translation: “drink your wine joyfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: drink your wine with a happy heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Bread” refers to food in general. Alternate translation: “Food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to the mind or will. Alternate translation: “The way a wise person thinks … the way a fool thinks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The heart of a wise person & the heart of a fool

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a ruler is represented by his “emotions” Alternate translation: “If a ruler becomes angry with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: If the emotions of a ruler rise up against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the wise man’s speech is represented by his “mouth.” Alternate translation: “The things that a wise man says are gracious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The words of a wise man’s mouth are gracious

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the fool’s speech is represented by his “lips.” This speaks of the fool destroying himself by his speech as if it were eating him. Alternate translation: “The things that a foolish man says destroy him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the lips of a fool consume him

contextId.occurrenceNote: A fool’s speech is represented by his “mouth.” Alternate translation: “As a fool begins to speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: As words begin to flow from a fool’s mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: A fool’s speech is represented by his “mouth.” Alternate translation: “as he finishes talking, he speaks wicked madness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: at the end his mouth flows with wicked madness

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person’s thoughts are represented by the person’s “mind.” Alternate translation: “not even in your thoughts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: not even in your mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “light” refers to being able to see the sun and therefore being alive. And, this speaks of the joy of being alive as if the light had a sweet taste. Alternate translation: “it is a joy to be able to see the sun” or “being alive is delightful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: light is sweet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” represents the emotions. Alternate translation: “be joyful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: let your heart be joyful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” may represent the mind or emotions. Alternate translation: “Pursue the good things that you desire” or “Pursue the good things that you have determined to pursue” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Pursue the good desires of your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “dust” refers to the human body that has decomposed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: dust returns to the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: amount to vapor & chasing the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: vapor & an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: vapor & an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how strenuously the person works. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: works so hard and tries in his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: vapor & an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: For everything there is an appointed time, and a season for every purpose

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how common wicked behavior is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I have seen the wickedness & wickedness was there

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “living” is a nominal adjective that refers to people who are living. The phrase “those who are still alive” means the same thing as “the living.” Alternate translation: “the people who are still alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the living, who are still alive

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: vapor & an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “alive” and “walking around” mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize living people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: alive & walking around

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: vapor & an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that you should think first before you speak to God about a matter. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not be too quick & do not let your heart be too quick

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. Alternate translation: “lives many years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: lives many years, so that the days of his years are many

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: vapor & an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: self-righteous, wise in your own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize people respecting God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: who respect God & who stand before him and show him respect

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings and emphasize the importance of enjoying the basic activities of life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: eat your bread with joy, and drink your wine with a happy heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. This speaks of people finding out what you have said as if a small bird would hear what you say and tell other people. Alternate translation: “For a bird may hear what you say and tell the matter to other people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For a bird of the sky & can spread the matter

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize that the man should be happy while he is young. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Take joy, young man, in your youth, and let your heart be joyful in the days of your youth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how the sun sets at the end of the day and is soon ready to rise again, as if it were a person that quickly ran from the place where it sets to the place from which it rises. Alternate translation: “quickly returns to the place” or “quickly goes to the place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: hurries back to the place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author speaks of using the wisdom that he had been taught to guide himself as if this wisdom were a person who guided him. Alternate translation: “I thought about the things that wise people had taught me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: I let my mind guide me with wisdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sorrow is spoken of as if it were a person that could follow someone else. Alternate translation: “the one who is alone when he falls is sorrowful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: sorrow follows the one who is alone when he falls

contextId.occurrenceNote: “but the wealth of a rich person keeps him awake at night.” This speaks of a rich person not being able to sleep because he is worried about his money as if his money were a person that would not allow him to sleep. Alternate translation: “but rich people do not sleep well because they worry about their money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: but the wealth of a rich person does not allow him to sleep well

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how wisdom helps to preserve a person’s life as if it gave life to that person. When a person is wise he makes good decisions that help him to live a more prosperous and longer life. Alternate translation: “preserves a person’s life” or “helps a person to make good decisions and to live a longer life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: gives life to whoever has it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of wickedness as if it were a master who had slaves. Alternate translation: “evil people will not be saved by doing what is evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: wickedness will not rescue those who are its slaves

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of “love” and “hate” as if they are people that may come to visit someone else. Alternate translation: “whether someone will experience love or hate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: whether love or hate will come to someone

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how a person acting foolishly can ruin his reputation as if his “folly” and “wisdom and honor” were people and that his folly overpowered his wisdom and honor. Alternate translation: “committing a little folly can ruin a person’s wisdom and honor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: a little folly can overpower wisdom and honor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that man’s work is pointless and has no lasting benefit. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Mankind gains no profit … under the sun.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What profit does mankind gain & under the sun?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is asked to emphasize that man cannot say there is anything new. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is nothing about which it may be said, ‘Look, this is new.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is there anything about which it may be said, ‘Look, this is new’?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses a rhetorical question to emphasize that pleasure is useless. Alternate translation: “It is useless.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What use is it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize his point that the next king will not be able to do anything more valuable that what he had already done. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “For the next king who comes after the king can do nothing that a king before him has not already done.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: For what can the next king do who comes after the king, which has not already been done?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is no benefit to being wise. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “So it makes no difference if I am very wise.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: So what difference does it make if I am very wise?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one knows the character the man who will inherit his wealth. Alternate translation: “For no one knows whether he will be a wise man or a fool.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: For who knows whether he will be a wise man or a fool?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that no pleasure can be had without God’s provision. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “For no one can eat or have any kind of pleasure apart from God.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: For who can eat or who can have any kind of pleasure apart from God?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one truly knows what happens after people and animals die. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one knows whether the spirit … into the earth.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who knows whether the spirit & into the earth?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one will see what happens after he dies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one of us knows what happens to us after we die.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who can bring him back to see what happens after him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a person lying down. The author use this rhetorical question to emphasize that two people can keep each other warm but one person cannot. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “a person cannot be warm when he is alone.” or “a person who lies down alone cannot be warm.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: how can one be warm alone?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that it is foolish to make a vow that you will not keep. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “It would be foolish to make God angry by vowing falsely, provoking God to destroy the work of your hands.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why make God angry by vowing falsely, provoking God to destroy the work of your hands?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that the wealthy do not benefit from their wealth. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The only benefit that the owner has from wealth is that he can look at it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What advantage in wealth is there to the owner except to watch it with his eyes?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is no benefit in working for the wind. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one gets any profit in working for the wind.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: So what profit is there for him who works for the wind?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that a wise person does not have any more lasting benefits than a fool. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “it seems the wise person has no advantage over the fool.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: what advantage has the wise person over the fool?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that a poor man does not have any more lasting benefits than someone else. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The poor man has no advantage even if he knows how to act in front of other people.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What advantage does the poor man have even if he knows how to act in front of other people?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is no advantage for a man to talk a lot. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “that is no advantage to a man.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: what advantage is that to a man?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that no person truly knows what is good for man. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one knows what is good for man … he passes like a shadow.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: For who knows what is good for man & he passes like a shadow?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one knows what will happen after a person dies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can tell a man … after he passes.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who can tell a man & after he passes?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person asks this rhetorical question in order to complain about the present time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Things were better in the past than they are now.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why were the days of old better than these?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one can change something that God has done. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can straighten out anything he has made crooked.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who can straighten out anything he has made crooked?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that being self-righteous destroys a person. Alternate translation: “There is no reason to destroy yourself.” or “If you think this way you will destroy yourself.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why should you destroy yourself?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is no reason for people to do things that will cause them to die early. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is no reason for you to die sooner than you should.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why should you die before your time?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses this rhetorical question to emphasize the difficulty in understanding wisdom. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can understand it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who can find it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question emphasizes that no one will ask the king the following question. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “no one can say to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: who will say to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is a rebuke. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You should not be doing what you are doing.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What are you doing?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question emphasizes that no one knows what will happen in the future. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one can tell him what is coming.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who can tell him what is coming?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer asks this question to emphasize that no one knows what will happen in the future after one’s death. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No one knows what is coming after him.” or “No one knows what will happen after he dies.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who knows what is coming after him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how everything in life vanishes and has no lasting value as if everything were like a disappearing vapor or breeze. Alternate translation: “Like a vapor of mist vanishes and like a breeze in the wind disappears, everything vanishes and has no lasting value” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like a vapor of mist, like a breeze in the wind, everything vanishes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how wisdom is better than folly by comparing it to how light is better than darkness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: wisdom has advantages over folly, just as light is better than darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author says that human beings are like animals. In the next verse the author explains clearly how humans are like animals. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: they are like animals

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how life passes quickly by saying that it is like a shadow that quickly disappears. The phrase “numbered days” emphasizes that a person’s life is short. Alternate translation: “during his futile, short life, which he passes through as quickly as a shadow passes by” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: in his life during his futile, numbered days through which he passes like a shadow

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how listening to fools talk and laugh will teach you nothing, as if their speech and laughter were the sound of burning thorns. Alternate translation: “For listening to the laughter of fools will not teach a man any more than if he were listening to the crackling of thorns burning under a pot” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: For like the crackling of thorns burning under a pot, so also is the laughter of fools

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as no one has the ability to stop himself from breathing, no one can continue living when it is time to die. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: No one is ruler over his breath so as to stop the breath & no one has power over the day of his death

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how the wicked man’s life passes quickly by saying that it is like a shadow that quickly disappears. Alternate translation: “His days will pass as quickly as a shadow disappears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His days are like a fleeting shadow

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “dog” was considered a lowly animal while a lion was considered a noble animal. This speaks of it being better to be lowly and alive than to be considered noble and dead. Alternate translation: “It is better to be lowly like a dog and to be alive than to be noble like a lion and to be dead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: just as a living dog is better than a dead lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of people dying when they do not expect it, in the same way that people catch animals and kill them when they do not expect it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: fish are caught & birds are caught & the children of human beings are ensnared

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as flies can ruin perfume, so folly can ruin a person’s reputation for wisdom and honor. This speaks of how a little folly can ruin a person’s reputation in the same way that a few dead flies ruin perfume. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: As dead flies & so a little folly

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of successful men walking like slaves walk, because slaves were usually forced to walk and were not permitted to ride. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: successful men walking like slaves on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a simile. Alternate translation: “Wise people encourage people to act, like a sharp stick encourages an animal to move” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The words of wise people are like goads

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a simile. Alternate translation: “Like you can depend on a nail that a person drives firmly into a piece of wood, so you can depend on the words of the masters in collections of their proverbs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like nails driven deeply are the words of the masters in collections of their proverbs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “eye” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “A person is not satisfied by what his eyes see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: The eye is not satisfied by what it sees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “ear” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “nor is a person content by what his ears hear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: nor is the ear fulfilled by what it hears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “mind” to emphasize his thoughts. Alternate translation: “I determined” or “I applied myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I applied my mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “I have spoken to myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I have spoken to my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “I determined” or “I applied myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I applied my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “I said to myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I said in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “eyes” to emphasize what he sees. Alternate translation: “Whatever I saw and desired … from myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Whatever my eyes desired & from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his desires. This can be stated positively and the word “pleasure” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “I did not keep myself from any pleasure” or “I allowed myself to enjoy everything that made me happy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I did not withhold my heart from any pleasure

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his desires. Alternate translation: “I rejoiced” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my heart rejoiced

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “hands.” Alternate translation: “all that I had accomplished” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: all the deeds that my hands had accomplished

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “I said to myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I said in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “I concluded” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I concluded in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “I began to despair” or “I began to lose all hope” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my heart began to despair

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “I said to myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I said in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author refers to himself by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “I said to myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I said in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the whole person is represented by his “eyes” to emphasize his desires. Alternate translation: “he is not satisfied” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: his eyes are not satisfied

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person is represented by his “heart” to emphasize his emotions and desires. Alternate translation: “do not” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: do not let your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person is represented by his “hands.” Alternate translation: “destroy everything you do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: destroy the work of your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a man by his “heart” to emphasize his feelings. Alternate translation: “he is not content with good things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: his heart is not satisfied with good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here wise people are referred to by their “hearts.” This speaks of the wise person mourning as being in a house of mourning. Alternate translation: “Wise people think deeply about death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here foolish people are referred to by their “hearts.” This speaks of foolish people thinking only about what makes them happy as being in a house of feasting. Alternate translation: “but foolish people think only about enjoying themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: but the heart of fools is in the house of feasting

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a man is represented by his “heart” to emphasize his thoughts. Alternate translation: “A wise man recognizes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: A wise man’s heart recognizes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people are represented by their “hearts” to emphasize their will and desires. Alternate translation: “entices human beings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: entices the hearts of human beings

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person is represented by his “eyes.” Alternate translation: “without sleeping” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: without sleep for the eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to food in general. Alternate translation: “your food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: your bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person is represented by his “hand” since a person often uses his hands to work. Alternate translation: “Whatever you are able to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Whatever your hand finds to do

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “king” represents himself and his whole army. Alternate translation: “a great king and his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: a great king came against it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a person is represented by his “hands” Alternate translation: “because of an idle person” or “because the person is idle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: because of idle hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the roof is represented by the whole house. Alternate translation: “the roof leaks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the house leaks

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Here “bones” is a synecdoche representing the baby as a whole. Alternate translation: “how a baby grows” or (2) literally, “how the bones of a baby grow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: how a baby’s bones grow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “keep on working” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: work with your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “eyes” represent the whole person. This phrase means basically the same thing as the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “for a person to see the sun” or “to be alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: for the eyes to see the sun

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” represent the whole person. Alternate translation: “whatever you see that you desire” or “whatever you see to be best” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: whatever is within the sight of your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “body” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “makes the person tired” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: brings weariness to the body

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “you” refers to himself. The word “happiness” can be expressed as an adjective. Alternate translation: “I will test myself with things that make me happy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I will test you with happiness
