contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “pleasure” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “So I will enjoy things that please me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: So enjoy pleasure

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “desires” may be expressed as a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “to use wine to make myself happy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: to gratify my desires with wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “envy” may be expressed as an adjective. Alternate translation: “made one’s neighbor envious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: became the envy of one’s neighbor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “produce” may be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “the food that the land produces … crops from the fields” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the produce of the land & produce from the fields

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “prosperity” may be expressed as an adjective. Alternate translation: “As a person becomes more prosperous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: As prosperity increases

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “sickness” and “anger” can be expressed as adjectives. Alternate translation: “suffers greatly, being sick and angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: is greatly distressed with sickness and anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “rebuke” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “when wise people rebuke you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: to the rebuke of the wise

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the reason for things.” This word “explanations” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “how to explain various things in life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: the explanations of reality

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “discovery” can be expressed as a verb. The word “adding” here is used as an idiom. Alternate translation: “discovering one thing after another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: adding one discovery to another

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nouns “work, “explanation,” and “knowledge” can be expressed as verbs. Alternate translation: “the dead do not work or explain or know or have wisdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: there is no work or explanation or knowledge or wisdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “laughter” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “People prepare food in order to laugh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: People prepare food for laughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “enjoyment” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “wine helps people to enjoy life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: wine brings enjoyment to life

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **judgment**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “judge” or “make you account” Alternate translation: “God will judge you for all these things” or “God will make you account for all of your actions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: God will bring you into judgment for all these things

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **desires**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “when people no longer desire what they once did naturally” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: when natural desires fail

Alternate translation: “whatever has happened before is what will happen again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.quoteString: about which it may be said

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people will not likely remember them either” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: will not likely be remembered either

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “everything that people do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Alternate translation: “People cannot straighten things that are twisted! They cannot count what is not there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “forest where trees grew” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: forest where trees were grown

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “People do not remember the wise man for very long, just as they do not remember the fool for very long” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people will have long forgotten everything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “all the work that people do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: all the work done

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “No one can add anything to or take anything away from it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Nothing can be added to it or taken away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be written in active form. Alternate translation: “Someone can overpower a person who is alone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: One man alone can be overpowered

contextId.quoteString: a three-strand rope is not quickly broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: “fathers 100 children.” This is a hypothetical situation. This is also an exaggeration and is applicable to people with fewer than 100 children. Alternate translation: “fathers many children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: fathers a hundred children

contextId.occurrenceNote: “2,000 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: two thousand years

contextId.occurrenceNote: “1 righteous man among 1,000.” Only one righteous man was found in a group of 1,000 people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: one righteous man among a thousand

contextId.occurrenceNote: “100 times” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: a hundred times

contextId.occurrenceNote: “7, even 8 people.” This is an idiom that means “numerous” people. Alternate translation: “numerous people” or “multiple people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: seven, even eight people
